8/ Web 3 emerging on top of Bitcoin is more than just a theory for me.

I believe in this outcome enough that the technical architecture of Stacks 2.0 and Clarity lang follows this model.

It‚Äôs exciting to see many different experiments and designs!

<finish>

7/ The ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù protocol that reaches market domination wins.

There can be only one narrow waist.

It doesn‚Äôt need to be perfect, but it absolutely needs to be universal.
6/ The narrow waist cannot be complex but radically simple.\n\nBitcoin fits that property. Other more complex blockchains don‚Äôt.

5/ A key property of internet‚Äôs narrow waist (IP protocol) is that its universal.

For a new protocol to become the ‚Äúnarrow waist‚Äù of crypto it‚Äôd need to become more universal than Bitcoin.

That‚Äôs theoretically possible but unlikely to happen.

4/ New protocols can anchor to security of Bitcoin and extend Bitcoin.

This is an under-explored design space but is beginning to change.

Clarity for example offers smart contracts that anchor to security of Bitcoin without modifying Bitcoin.
3/ Bitcoin has network effects.\n\nIf something can be done on top of Bitcoin, it will eventually get done on top of Bitcoin vs a smaller ecosystem.

2/ Bitcoin is not merely a payment application of consensus protocols.

It‚Äôs the largest, most stable consensus protocol that is minimal by design.

IP is minimal by design; it does one job and does it well. Same for Bitcoin.

A great thread on narrow waist model from the internet applied to crypto.

I present a variation that argues for Bitcoin as narrow waist for Web 3.

@oryband There seems to be a myth that if you solve TPS you magically get Web 3. \n\nTPS focused thinking might be leading people in the wrong direction.
@oryband Decentralization guarantees of each layer, scalability of end-to-end user interactions (across layers), long-term reliability of data storage, end-to-end performance of apps.

Solving for high ‚Äútransactions per second‚Äù (TPS) seems to be the ‚Äúholy grail‚Äù for new crypto protocols.\n\nThe contrarian view here is that the bulk of scalability challenges are outside of base-layer transactions and TPS is a bad metric to optimize.

RT @arjunblj: The crypto analyst's version of designing your own consensus mechanism is creating a new on-chain indicator.

Sharding itself introduces coordination complexity. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúmagic‚Äù. 

There is a trade off b/w added complexity and potential scaling benefits, *depending on workloads*.

Coordination complexity between even a few well-defined shards would give (good) systems engineers pause.

Sharding works under well-defined application workloads where you can localize interactions clearly in a shard.\n\nApp workloads in blockchains are random, you can‚Äôt predict what function will interact with what.

A lot of technical arguments in crypto take the form of ‚Äú... because sharding‚Äù.

The concept of sharding is fairly misunderstood in crypto and has morphed beyond recognition from the traditional use in distributed systems.

Some thoughts:

@bznotes @mikepstanley https://t.co/51pOugIhuf for anyone who is interested.

@odinho @blockstack We're not engaging with standards bodies that actively due to limited bandwidth (more focused on building things developers want). With that said, we're part of the Decentralized Identity Foundation. CC: @csuwildcat

Distributed systems engineers struggle to keep systems consistent and reliable *within* a datacenter.\n\nArmchair scientists in crypto are confident in scaling global state with random peers in random countries.

Users hit the Facebook like button something like 5 billion times a day, and that‚Äôd trigger more than 5 billion state/view changes for the FB app.\n\nTry calculating the ‚ÄúTPS‚Äù for a single social network. (When did we start measuring stuff in ‚ÄúTPS‚Äù anyway?)

When designing scalable distributed systems I‚Äôm worried about speed of syncing memory data to (local) disk.\n\nPeople in crypto want all data from all apps replicated on remote computers with global state changes ü§Ø

@ali01 Think @iam_preethi can host a debate. Happy to discuss more.\n\nMain thing I‚Äôd point out is that you seem to be underestimating the level of global coordination and global data sharing required for anything close to a logical ‚Äúworld computer‚Äù. :-)
@spencernoon More context here: https://t.co/RnKcAWFygI

6/ Global blockchains are good for a handful of things if used wisely, let‚Äôs use them for what they‚Äôre good at and not for things they‚Äôre horrible at.\n\nFinally, Twitter is a horrible medium for technical discussions. If what I said offended you, let‚Äôs talk offline üôè

5/ The ‚Äúworld computer‚Äù marketing has done enough harm to our industry with wildly unrealistic expectations where a blockchain will store all data, run all programs, for all users at a global internet scale.\n\nLet‚Äôs please stop that non-sense.

4/ By definition any node on L1 can trigger a state change that needs to be reflected on all other nodes before the global network can make progress. \n\nState changes are not local but global at this layer. If your state changes are not global, we‚Äôre using different definitions.

3/ The fundamental limits I talk about are (asymmetric) bandwidth links for a global decentralized p2p network.\n\nYou can‚Äôt shove terabytes of data through these pipes and expect these nodes to keep up. There are limits, so let‚Äôs operate within those limits.
2/ The focus of my argument is on ‚Äúdo less at the blockchain layer‚Äù and not on the ‚Äúblockchains don‚Äôt scale‚Äù part.\n\nCan L1 scaling be improved over what‚Äôs currently available? Sure.
1/ This offhand comment I made seems to be tripping up people. \n\nSome more context: https://t.co/oVFJSAAMZl

(b) there are limits on how much data can be synced between p2p nodes vs the false idea of a ‚Äúworld computer‚Äù.

Eventual consistency has helped scale out distributed systems at Amazon, amongst other things.

This article by Werner Vogels (Amazon CTO) is a good overview:

https://t.co/ckT9PHHAxW

Gilbert and Lynch (MIT) formally proved the CAP theorem:

https://t.co/u51Sf7V6LK

Designers of large-scale distributed systems make regular use of CAP.
CAP theorem and eventual consistency are extremely important concepts in distributed systems with real implications. https://t.co/IAj4rvIWpe

@VladZamfir @dougvk @chainyoda @neha Binary Consensus is an algorithm (if we‚Äôre talking about the same thing) and ‚Äúglobal‚Äù in global consensus simply means a network spread across the entire world.\n\nI did say earlier that long-form or in-person would be better :-)

@VladZamfir @neha Just sharing a data point here that I‚Äôve been going to distributed systems conferences for 10 years and I‚Äôve never gotten into a discussion about ‚Äúwhat is global consensus?‚Äù.\n\nThe distributed systems community agrees on definitions of terms and it‚Äôd help to just use them.
@VladZamfir @neha Wait, what is your definition of global consensus? That nodes can disagree on global state?

@VladZamfir @neha I'm sure you have and I appreciate the effort you're putting in. \n\nThe distributed systems community as a whole has been working on consensus protocols for 20-30 years; there are well-defined, well-understood limits when it comes to scaling global consensus.

@VladZamfir @neha The "globally consistent" is the tricky part there. Anything that is globally consistent (regardless of how it's derived, local decisions or not) has fundamental limitations that you need to work with.
@VladZamfir @neha Scale without L2? Would love to learn about what all you envision can be done at L1 on-chain (within limits of physics and distributed systems).

@VladZamfir I view L2 as a use-case of L1 and L1 should be agnostic to usecases. The more real use it‚Äôs getting, the better it is for economic incentives in general.\n\nHowever, there are some issues e.g., certain L2 incentives (like mining a L2 block) can incentivize miner attacks at L1.
@VladZamfir We‚Äôve been running a production L2 network for years. It forced us to look deeper into L1 security e.g., we discovered and reported Namecoin L1 mining issues and moved to Bitcoin L1.
@VladZamfir I‚Äôd argue the opposite. \n\nL2 gives added incentives to improve and test the security of L1.

10/ Human brain is a lot more complex than any known computer system. But some CS concepts apply, leaving the possibility open to me that we might already be living in a simulation in which we're trying to (re-)invent the science that already dictates our existence.

9/ We talk a lot about networks of processors inside a single brain rearranging and learning but not enough about the connection of these networks to other networks in other brains. Long before the WWW, our brains were already connected to others in an "internet" (inter-network).
8/ The deepest level of storage (and probably storing the most amount of data) might be in the unconsious domain. When you sleep a lot of background processes chew up and rearrange this data.

7/ There is working memory (very similar to RAM) and long-term memory (very similar to disk). However, I think that the same data is saved at various levels of compression/granularity many times over i.e., a network of storage systems saving same data for many use cases.
6/ There seems to be intelligence (machine learning?) dedicated to focusing on patterns on the I/O data and throwing away the raw data. Which brings me to data storage.

5/ The I/O to our brain works differently from contemporary computers; most of the data from input devices (eyes for examples) gets thrown away. Imagine I/O devices sophisticated enough to generate data at a rate that you cannot process or store.

4/ The I/O of our brain works fairly similar to operating system interrupts. Your eye (visual input) sees a car coming, send an interrupt "drop whatever you're doing and pay attention to that car now!".

3/ I don't think our brain is a computer processor; it's probably a network of small processors. In fact, two large networks of processors (right and left hemisphere) that can function independently but are strangely connected.
2/ If we try to use known computer science concepts to describe a human brain, what would the model look like?\n\nI love that question. I don't think we have answers yet. Here is a theory.
1/ A naive computer model for a human brain.\n\n(A thread of ideas too half-baked to be a blog post.)

@BitcoinsSG You can definitely do both but I want to emphasize which path has fundamental (physical) limitations.
@AdamPaigge @FEhrsam Compression helps but these are marginal benefits.
@FEhrsam Hat tip @JudeCNelson for discussions on this and the straw analogy. (I was going for the Holland Tunnel between Manhattan & Jersey analogy.)
@SambodhiPrem @FEhrsam They're very different models. You can have a Facebook-like blockchain app but the architecture will be very different.
@desantis @SambodhiPrem @FEhrsam Hey, I listen to Fred :-)
@brianchoffman @FEhrsam His view is that scalability is multidimensional (and I can see his point). I feel there is a big elephant in the room w/ other small things
@FEhrsam 9/ Next time scalability comes up, let's remember straws. We can twist them, break them, but we cannot push more liquids through them.
@FEhrsam 8/ My prediction is that protocols that focus on minimizing on-chain data instead of trying to scale on-chain will end up winning.
@FEhrsam 7/ Decentralized networks need to sync data over low-bandwidth pipes w/ nodes all over the world. Can't compare this to client/server model.
@FEhrsam 6/ The centralized systems of Google and Facebook are a different beast. It's high-speed direct client/server connections to datacenters.
@FEhrsam 5/ We can give every blockchain user a super computer but the network link will sadly still be these pipes/straws.
@FEhrsam 4/ Internet pipes are like straws. Doesn't matter how you hold a straw or what container you use, only a limited amount of fluid can flow.
@FEhrsam 3/ The elephant in the room for scaling blockchains is the physical internet pipes that connect us. That's the choke point.
@FEhrsam 2/ For scaling computer systems the first rule is to correctly identify the bottleneck. Otherwise, we're optimizing the wrong things.
1/ .@FEhrsam nails it that "I believe scalability will be the primary bottleneck for the [blockchain] industry for the foreseeable future."
